column1: Levin (Māori: Taitoko) is the largest town and seat of the Horowhenua District
column2: in the Manawatū-Whanganui region of New Zealand's North Island. It is located east of Lake Horowhenua
column3: around 95 km north of Wellington and 50 km southwest of Palmerston North.

column1: == History and culture ==
=== 20th century ===
The Levin township was established in 1906.
The town was named after William Hort Levin
column2: a director of the Wellington and Manawatu Railway Company.The name is a variation of the Jewish clan Levi. It is a shibboleth – unlike the usual pronunciation of the surname
column3: stress is placed on the second syllable of the word. However his great grandson
column5: claims his forebear would have pronounced his surname as in Levene and this pronunciation was in common use for many years and always used by the family.
